definition: Zhang Qian (-114 BC), Han dynasty explorer of 2nd century BC
surname Zhang
to open up/to spread/sheet of paper/classifier for flat objects, sheet/classifier for votes
defective/raise

sentences.english: Han's open-up at the borders policy and Zhang Qian's travel to western countries successfully opened the Silk Road .
sentences.chinese: 汉代的开边政策和张骞通西域成功地开通了丝绸之路。

sentences.english: The main goods that Zhang Qian brings at that time is silk.
sentences.chinese: 张骞当时带出去的主要货物是丝绸。

definition: Ban Chao (33-102), noted Han diplomat and military man
the Greater Yuezhi, a branch of the Yuezhi 月氏[Yue4 zhi1] people of central Asia during the Han dynasty
Han Dynasty (206 BC-220 AD)
Su Wu (140-60 BC), Han Dynasty diplomat and statesman, regarded as a model of courage and faithful service
Emperor Wu of the Han dynasty (141-87 BC)
Li Ling (-74 BC), Han dynasty general whose defeat by the Xiongnu 匈奴 in 104 BC led to a major scandal
ancient state of central Asia
Xiongnu, a people of the Eastern Steppe who created an empire that flourished around the time of the Qin and Han dynasties
Western Regions (Han Dynasty term for regions beyond Yumen Pass 玉門關|玉门关[Yu4 men2 Guan1])
Li Guang (-119 BC), Han dynasty general, nicknamed Flying General 飛將軍|飞将军 and much feared by the Xiongnu 匈奴
Wusun kingdom of central Asia (c. 300 BC-300 AD)
lit. to return east/fig. to return to one's homeland
ancient Central Asian city state, flourished in first millennium AD, in modern Aksu 阿克蘇地區|阿克苏地区, Xinjiang
Parthia
Hexi Corridor (or Gansu Corridor), a string of oases running the length of Gansu, forming part of the Northern Silk Road
Western Han Dynasty (206 BC-8 AD), also called 前漢|前汉[Qian2 Han4], Former Han Dynasty
